properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Maximum gusts: Southwesterly between 100 and 130 km/h. Locations: southern half of the Burin Peninsula, most of the Avalon Peninsula. Time span: midnight Wednesday night to Thursday morning. Remarks: After the southwesterlies diminish Thursday morning, winds will shift to northwesterly. Over the northern Avalon Peninsula winds will likely gust between 80 and 100 km/h Thursday afternoon. Additionally, large waves and pounding surf are expected in Placentia and St. Mary's Bay over Wednesday night. Water levels may be higher than normal during that time giving the potential for minor coastal flooding, especially near high tide. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may cause downed trees or toss loose objects. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-08T11:51:15-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-07T19:52:15-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2242866879.2020
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Burin Peninsula
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A Pacific frontal system will track across southern B.C. today bringing heavy snowfall to the Trans - Canada Highway from Eagle Pass to Rogers Pass. Total snowfall accumulations from this morning to Wednesday morning will top 25 cm. Snow will taper to a few flurries as the system exits the province on Wednesday morning. ### Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Expect road closures as avalanches are possible. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-08T09:34:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-07T17:35:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2825033044.2020
Area: Trans-Canada Highway - Eagle Pass to Rogers Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter storm conditions likely Wednesday night and Thursday. Total snowfall: 15 to 30 cm (10 to 20 cm Wednesday night, 5 to 10 cm Thursday) Maximum wind gusts: Easterly 60 to 80 km/h (Wednesday night), north to northwesterly 80 to 120 km/h (Thursday). Time span: Wednesday afternoon to Thursday evening. Remarks: A low pressure system will cross southeastern Newfoundland on Wednesday night into Thursday morning. Snow will begin along the south coast on Wednesday afternoon and spread elsewhere by evening. Some areas in northeastern Newfoundland may see a brief change over to rain or drizzle overnight on Wednesday night before changing back to snow again on Thursday. Strong winds will combine with falling snow to reduce visibility in blowing snow, especially in the northeast on Thursday. Conditions will improve in the south and central by mid day on Thursday, but will continue in the west and northeast until Thursday evening. At this time, the Great Northern Peninsula may receive the least amount of snow, with potentially less snow than mentioned above. However, a shift in the track could bring those heavier amounts further north. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-08T06:31:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-07T14:32:02-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0809919158.2020
Area: Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity, Corner Brook and vicinity, Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Gros Morne, Bay St. George, Buchans and the interior, Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Gander and vicinity, Green Bay - White Bay, Northern Peninsula East, Parson's Pond - Hawke's Bay, Port Saunders and the Straits
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, blowing snow and strong winds for Thursday. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm (5 to 10 cm Wednesday night, 5 cm Thursday) Maximum wind gusts: Easterly 60 to 80 km/h (Wednesday night), north to northwesterly 80 to 120 km/h (Thursday). Locations: Eastern and Northeastern Newfoundland. Time span: late Wednesday afternoon to Thursday evening. Remarks: A low pressure system will cross eastern Newfoundland on Wednesday night into Thursday morning. Snow will begin late Wednesday afternoon before changing to rain or drizzle near midnight on Wednesday night. Rain will change back to snow before morning on Thursday causing conditions to deteriorate throughout the day. Strong north to northwesterly winds will develop Thursday morning, combining with fresh snow to produce poor visibility in blowing snow. Wind warnings are likely, blowing snow advisories are possible. Conditions will improve Thursday evening as the winds and snow diminish. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-08T11:44:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-07T19:45:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0465383903.2020
Area: Bonavista North, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity, Gander and vicinity, Terra Nova
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow expected on Wednesday. Locations: central and eastern Prince Edward Island. Time span: Wednesday and persisting into Wednesday night. Remarks: A developing storm will give significant snowfall to central and eastern parts of the province on Wednesday. The snow will develop Wednesday morning and persist into the evening, then taper to flurries overnight. Current indications suggest that total snowfall of 10 to 15 cm is likely by Wednesday afternoon with an additional 2 to 4 cm possible overnight. Additionally, strong northerly winds will develop giving reduced visibility in blowing snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-08T11:46:58-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-07T19:47:58-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1469013959.2020
Area: Kings County P.E.I., Queens County P.E.I.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A Pacific frontal system crossing southern B.C. today will bring near 25 cm of snow to Fernie and Morrissey by Wednesday morning. The heavy snow is expected to ease somewhat tonight and then become intermittent on Wednesday as the system exits the province. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-08T09:34:05-00:00

Area: Elk Valley
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Frontal snow squalls expected early this evening. A cold front will move rapidly southeastward over the region early this evening and near zero visibility due to blowing snow and a quick accumulation of snow is expected. Snow accumulations may only be a few centimetres however travel may be hazardous at times this evening. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-08T05:59:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-07T18:58:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2911434483.2020
Area: Blind River - Thessalon, Espanola - Killarney, Manitoulin Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: More snow and wind expected Wednesday night and Thursday. Possible total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm (5 to 10 cm Wednesday night, 5 to 10 cm Thursday) Possible wind gusts: Easterly 60 to 80 km/h (Wednesday evening), southwesterly 80 to 120 km/h (overnight Wednesday night), northwesterly 80 to 120 km/h (Thursday afternoon). Time span: Wednesday afternoon to Thursday evening. Remarks: A low pressure system will cross southeastern Newfoundland on Wednesday night into Thursday morning. Snow will begin along the south coast on Wednesday afternoon and spread elsewhere by evening. Precipitation will change over to rain or drizzle by Wednesday evening with some minor rainfall amounts possible. Precipitation will change back to snow again overnight Wednesday night before continuing into the day on Thursday. Any significant blowing snow will likely only occur Thursday afternoon after the snow redevelops and the temperatures fall below freezing. Conditions will improve in the south Thursday morning, but will linger in the east until Thursday evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-08T06:31:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-07T14:32:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0700250145.2020

properties.Title: Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory For The Town Of Ituna.
properties.Summary:
Description: A Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory has been issued for all properties and residents located North of the Railway Tracks in the Town of Ituna. This advisory is for all properties and residents located North of the Railway Tracks in the Town of Ituna and for any individuals who may access water from the affected area of the water system. This advisory is in effect until January 14, 2020.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls expected today. Lake effect snow squalls are expected to develop in a west flow off Lake Superior this afternoon. Near zero visibility is also possible as a cold front moves southeastward over the region later this afternoon. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm by later tonight will be possible along with significant reductions to visibility under the most intense bands. Snow squall activity will shift southward overnight as winds become northerly. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-08T10:40:50-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-07T18:41:50-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0999108856.2020

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. A frontal snow squall will cross the regions tonight and then lake effect snow bands will continue in a few areas into Wednesday morning. A cold front moving over the regions from Lake Huron and Georgian Bay will give low visibilities and a quick accumulation of snow this evening. Then winds will become northwesterly and isolated lake effect snow squalls will develop. Some of the snow squalls may give snowfall accumulations in excess of 15 centimetres by Wednesday morning. Travel may become hazardous tonight into Wednesday. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-08T12:09:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-07T20:10:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1183033729.2020

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Maximum wind gusts: north to northwesterly 80 km/h, stronger gusts are possible. Total Snowfall: 5 to 10 cm. Location: Great Northern Peninsula. Time span: Wednesday night to mid day Thursday. Remarks: Modest snowfall will combine with strengthening winds to cause poor visibility in blowing snow over the Great Northern Peninsula beginning after midnight on Wednesday night. Strong winds and periods of snow will continue into Thursday morning before tapering off later in the day. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-08T11:44:50-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-07T19:45:50-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1170635900.2020

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Brief, intense snowfall is expected. Visibilities will be rapidly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow. Frontal snow squall this afternoon. A cold front moving southeastward across the region this afternoon will give near zero visibilities in snow and blowing snow. Roads will be quickly become snow covered. Later this afternoon lake effect snow squalls from Lake Superior will give local amounts of 10 to 20 centimetres. These snow squalls may be impacting areas near Wawa and southward late this afternoon and tonight. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. A frontal snow squall will cross the regions later this evening and then lake effect snow bands will continue in a few areas into Wednesday morning. A cold front moving over the regions from Lake Huron will give low visibilities and a quick accumulation of snow later this evening. Then winds will become northwesterly overnight and isolated lake effect snow squalls will develop. Some of the snow squalls may give snowfall accumulations in excess of 15 centimetres by Wednesday morning, especially northeast of London. Isolated snow squalls may continue into Wednesday afternoon. Travel may become hazardous tonight into Wednesday. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Extreme cold wind chill values near -50 have developed in portions of the northern Mackenzie valley and South Delta regions. Wind chill values are expected to moderate this afternoon, however extreme cold conditions are likely again tonight. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts near 15 cm is expected. A low pressure centre will cross the central coast this afternoon. Associated with the system, snow will continue over the inland sections of the central coast today and tonight. Snow will be mixed with rain this afternoon. Total snowfall amounts near 15 cm are expected by Wednesday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, continues. A moist Pacific frontal system is bringing rain to the South Coast of BC. Heavy rain started last night. The heavy rain will continue this morning and finally ease late this afternoon as the storm system leaves the region. Total rainfall accumulations of 60 to 90 mm are expected. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-08T11:02:28-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:

The snow is forecast to continue into this afternoon becoming mixed with rain at times. Total snowfall accumulations of up to 40 cm are expected by this evening. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Wind chill temperatures near minus 40 degrees Celsius are expected overnight with slight warming during the daytime hours before cooling off again tomorrow night. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow on Wednesday. Location: western and northern Nova Scotia. Time span: beginning early Wednesday morning and persisting into Wednesday night. Remarks: A developing storm will give significant snowfall to the province on Wednesday. The snow will develop Wednesday morning and then begin to taper to flurries in the afternoon in the west and evening in the north. Current indications suggest total snowfall of 10 to 15 cm but more is possible if the storm track should shift to the west as it develops. Snowfall warnings may be expanded westward in future updates. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Brief, intense snowfall is expected. Visibilities will be rapidly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow. Frontal snow squall expected this afternoon. A cold front moving southeastward across the region this afternoon will give near zero visibilities in snow and blowing snow. Roads will be quickly become snow covered. Later this afternoon lake effect snow squalls from Lake Superior will give local amounts of 10 to 20 centimetres. These snow squalls may be impacting areas near Wawa and southward late this afternoon and tonight. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-08T10:33:50-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-07T18:35:50-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0905238570.2020
Area: White River - Dubreuilville, Wawa - Pukaskwa Park, Agawa - Lake Superior Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow at times heavy on Wednesday. Total snowfall: 20 to 30 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 50 to 70 km/h. Location: central and eastern Nova Scotia. Time span: Wednesday and persisting into Wednesday night. Remarks: A developing storm will give significant snowfall to the province on Wednesday. The snow will develop Wednesday morning and then begin to taper to flurries in the evening over mainland Nova Scotia and overnight in Cape Breton. Current indications suggest total snowfall of 20 to 30 cm by Thursday morning, with higher amounts possible over the Cape Breton Highlands. Additionally, strong northerly winds will develop giving reduced visibility in blowing snow. Higher than normal water levels are expected at high tide Wednesday afternoon or evening along the Cape Breton coastline and the southern Gulf of St. Lawrence. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. There may be a significant impact on rush hour traffic in urban areas. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-08T11:50:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-07T19:51:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4294187125.2020
Area: Lunenburg County, Hants County, Colchester County - Truro and south, Halifax Metro and Halifax County West, Halifax County - east of Porters Lake, Pictou County, Guysborough County, Antigonish County, Richmond County, Inverness County - south of Mabou, Inverness County - Mabou and north, Victoria County, Sydney Metro and Cape Breton County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly near 70 km/h Wednesday evening, northwesterly near 70 km/h Wednesday night and Thursday morning. Total Snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Location: Inland over the Burgeo highway. Time span: Wednesday afternoon to early Thursday morning. Remarks: Fresh snow and moderate winds will combine to cause poor visibility in blowing snow, especially inland along the Burgeo highway. Conditions along the coast should be less severe. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-08T11:38:22-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-07T19:39:22-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1324172980.2020
Area: Burgeo - Ramea
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A strong Pacific frontal system spread snow to the Sea to Sky Highway and Whistler region last night. The snow is forecast to continue into this afternoon becoming mixed with rain at times. Total snowfall accumulations of up to 40 cm are expected by this evening. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-08T01:59:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-07T19:01:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2975559020.2020
Area: Sea to Sky - Squamish to Whistler
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Extreme cold wind chill values near -50 have developed in portions of the northern Mackenzie valley and South Delta regions. Wind chill values are expected to moderate this afternoon, however extreme cold conditions are likely again tonight. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-08T09:30:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-07T17:31:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3313527825.2020
Area: Norman Wells - Tulita Region, Fort Good Hope Region, Colville Lake

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A low pressure system crossing the Chilcotin today will produce 10 to 15 cm of snow over parts of the Chilcotin today. The most likely areas to see heavy snow accumulations are north of Tatla Lake, towards Anahim Lake. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and blowing snow expected late Wednesday and Thursday. Total Snowfall: 15 to 30 cm. Maximum wind gusts: Generally northwesterly near 80 km/h. Northwesterly gusts near 100 km/h are expected in the Port Aux Basques area overnight Wednesday night. Gusts between 100 and 120 km/h will develop along the northeast coast on Thursday morning. Locations: Port Aux Basque to Gros Morne, Central and Northeastern Newfoundland. Time span: Wednesday afternoon or evening to Thursday evening. Remarks: Snow at times heavy will combine with strong winds to reduce visibility in blowing snow Wednesday night and Thursday. Conditions will gradually improve by Thursday evening as winds and snow diminish. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Wind chill values of minus 50 or colder will persist tonight. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A Pacific frontal system will track across southern B.C. today. Heavy snow will continue today and tonight giving 30 to 50 cm. Total accumulations near 70 cm is likely by Wednesday morning. Snow will ease Wednesday morning as the system exits the province. ### Rapidly accumulating snow and drifting snow will make travel very difficult. Poor weather conditions are likely to contribute to long-lasting transportation delays. Expect road closures as avalanches are possible. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
